Chapter 15, Part 2: The Factors of Awakening, continued. What is the factor of awakening of tranquility?
The World-Honored One said:

Ä€nanda, you should know that when entering the first concentration, speech is stilled, and due to this condition, other dharmas are also stilled. This is called the first characteristic conducive to tranquility.

When entering the second concentration, investigation and analysis are stilled, and due to this condition, other dharmas are also stilled. This is called the second characteristic conducive to tranquility.
When entering the third concentration, all joy is stilled, and due to this condition, other dharmas are also stilled. This is called the third characteristic conducive to tranquility.

When entering the fourth concentration, inhalation and exhalation are stilled, and due to this condition, other dharmas are also stilled. This is called the fourth characteristic conducive to tranquility.

When entering the concentration of cessation of ideation and feeling, ideation and feeling are quiescent, and due to this condition, other dharmas are also quiescent. This is called the fifth aspect conducive to lightness and comfort.

Ä€nanda should know that there is also a sixth supreme lightness and comfort, which is superior and most superior, which is the highest and unsurpassed. Such lightness and comfort is the highest and most wonderful, and no other lightness and comfort can surpass it.
What is this again?
It refers to the mind being liberated from the defilement of greed, and liberated from the defilement of hatred and delusion. This is called the sixth aspect conducive to lightness and comfort.

The lightness and comfort of the body, the lightness and comfort of the mind, the nature of lightness and comfort, and the kind of lightness and comfort associated with the uncontaminated attention that contemplates these aspects are collectively called lightness and comfort, and are also called the factor of awakening of lightness and comfort. They are holy, worldly, uncontaminated, not grasped at, and are the practice of the path that accompanies the path, that accompanies and turns with the path, and are able to completely end suffering and make suffering cease.

All learners, as they see various conditioned states, contemplate and investigate them to the ultimate, deeply seeing the faults in conditioned states and deeply seeing the merits in ultimate nirvana.

If arhats, like the liberated mind, contemplate and investigate to the ultimate, all the bodily lightness, mental lightness, lightness nature, and lightness type associated with the undefiled attention, this is called the factor of enlightenment of lightness.
What is the factor of enlightenment of concentration?

The World-Honored One said:ğŸ”½Bhiká¹£us, you should know that I say one can end all defilements by relying on the first concentration. Thus, I say one can end all defilements by relying on the second, third, fourth concentrations, the sphere of infinite space, the sphere of infinite consciousness, and the sphere of nothingness.
Bhiká¹£us, you should know that I rely on what I say to say this. By relying on the first concentration, one can end all defilements.

It is said that a certain bhiká¹£u, by means of such characteristics and appearances, separated from desires, separated from evil and unwholesome states, with initial and sustained thought, joy and happiness born of separation, abided in the first meditative absorption.

He did not contemplate such characteristics and appearances, but only contemplated the form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness that he had attained and was progressing towards, thinking that these dharmas were like a disease, like an ulcer, like an arrow, harmful, impermanent, suffering, empty, and non-self.
He deeply detested, feared, and stopped these dharmas, and then concentrated his mind on the realm of immortality.
He contemplated that this realm was tranquil and subtle, abandoning all dependence, with the exhaustion of craving, separation from desire, complete cessation, and nirvÄá¹‡a.
It is like a skilled archer or his disciple first practicing close-range shooting at clay or straw targets, and later being able to shoot far and break through even very solid objects.

The bhiká¹£us are also like this. First, by means of such characteristics and appearances, they are free from desires, evil and unwholesome dharmas, have initial and sustained thought, and abide in the first concentration with joy and pleasure born of seclusion.

They do not contemplate such characteristics and appearances, but only contemplate the form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness that they have attained and are heading towards, thinking that these dharmas are like a disease, like an ulcer, like an arrow, harmful, impermanent, suffering, empty, and not self.

They deeply detest, fear, and stop these dharmas, and then gather their minds and place them in the realm of immortality, contemplating that this realm is tranquil and subtle, abandoning all dependence, with the exhaustion of craving, free from defilements, eternally extinguished, and nirvÄá¹‡a.
Because they know and see in this way, they are liberated from the desire-leakage in their minds, and they are also liberated from the existence-leakage and ignorance-leakage in their minds.
Having been liberated, they are able to know and see for themselves that they have attained liberation:
I have ended birth, established the holy life, done what was to be done, and will not undergo another existence.'
I rely on this to say that by relying on the first meditation one can exhaust the defilements.

Just as it is said that by relying on the first meditation one can exhaust the defilements, it is said that by relying on the second, third, fourth meditations, the sphere of infinite space, the sphere of infinite consciousness, and the sphere of nothingness one can exhaust the defilements.
It is the same as appropriate, that is to say, the second meditation should be spoken of in this way.

Moreover, there is a bhiká¹£u who, by means of such characteristics and appearances, the tranquility of applied and sustained thought, the internal purity of the mind's one-pointed nature, the birth of joy and pleasure without applied and sustained thought, dwells in the second meditation in its entirety.
He does not contemplate such characteristics and appearances, and so on at length.

Up to the sphere of nothingness, it should be said that there is also a bhiká¹£u who, by such characteristics and appearances, transcends all kinds of the sphere of infinite consciousness and enters the sphere of nothingness, abiding in fullness.

He does not contemplate such characteristics and appearances, but only contemplates the feelings, perceptions, mental formations, and consciousness that he has attained and is heading towards, and so on.

Bhiká¹£us should know that up to the attainment of concentration can accomplish such things that should be done, and there is also the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception and the attainment of cessation.
I say that for those bhiká¹£us who cultivate concentration there, they should frequently enter and emerge from it.

When cultivating these seven bases of concentration, the mind abiding in union with the uncontaminated mental activities, and the mind abiding in equipoise up to the one-pointedness of mind, are collectively called concentration, also called the faculty of concentration, also called the power of concentration, also called the factor of awakening of concentration, also called right concentration, which is the noble, supramundane, uncontaminated, unapprehending path, the practice in accordance with the path, the simultaneous arising with the path, the turning together with the path, which is able to completely end suffering and make suffering cease.

Those in training contemplate and investigate the various phenomena as they have seen them, bringing them to completion. They deeply see the faults within the various phenomena and deeply see the merits of complete nirvana.

If an arhat, with a liberated mind, contemplates and investigates, bringing it to completion, the uncontaminated mental activities in union with the mind abiding in equipoise up to the one-pointedness of mind, this is called the factor of awakening of concentration.
What is the factor of awakening of equanimity?

It is said that a bhiká¹£u contemplates the realm of cessation, the realm of separation, and the realm of extinction. Because of this, he gives rise to the nature of mental equality, the nature of mental uprightness, and the nature of tranquil abiding without mental exertion.
He thinks like this:
I should now be free from greed, anger, and delusion regarding dharmas that accord with greed, anger, and delusion.
Because of this, he gives rise to the nature of mental equality, the nature of mental uprightness, and the nature of tranquil abiding without mental exertion. He further thinks like this:
I should now not accept greed, anger, and delusion in the mind.
Because of this, he gives rise to the nature of mental equality, the nature of mental uprightness, and the nature of tranquil abiding without mental exertion.

The non-outflow thought associated with the six kinds of equanimity that are in accordance with the Dharma, the nature of the mind being impartial, the nature of the mind being upright, the nature of the mind being free from agitation and peacefully abiding, is generally called equanimity, also called the factor of enlightenment of equanimity, which is holy, supramundane, non-outflow, not grasped at, following the path, coexisting with the path, and turning with the path, able to completely end suffering and make suffering cease.

Those in training, as they see the various practices, contemplate and observe them to reach the ultimate, deeply seeing the faults in the various practices, and deeply seeing the merits in ultimate nirvana.

If arhats, as they understand the liberated mind, contemplate and observe it to reach the ultimate, the non-outflow thought associated with the nature of the mind being impartial, the nature of the mind being upright, the nature of the mind being free from agitation and peacefully abiding, this is called the factor of enlightenment of equanimity.

What is craving?

It is the various forms of craving, such as craving for sensual desires, which are grasped, guarded, clung to, and adhered to with love and affection, and which are indulged in and enjoyed, internally bound, and desired. It is the suffering and origin of suffering that arises from craving, and is collectively called craving.
What is hatred?

It is collectively called hatred.
What is delusion?

It is ignorance regarding the past, ignorance regarding the future, and ignorance regarding the past and future. It is ignorance regarding the internal, ignorance regarding the external, and ignorance regarding the internal and external. It is ignorance regarding karma, ignorance regarding ripening, and ignorance regarding karma and its ripening. Ignorance of dependently arisen dharmas, not knowing the six sense bases as they really are.

Such ignorance, lack of knowledge, lack of insight, darkness, stupidity, blindness of ignorance, net of ignorance, dullness and confusion, covering that causes blindness, causing blindness, causing lack of eyes, causing lack of wisdom, causing inferior wisdom, obstructing wholesome qualities, preventing nirvana, the defilement of ignorance, the flood of ignorance, the yoke of ignorance, the poisonous root of ignorance, the poisonous trunk of ignorance, the poisonous branches of ignorance, the poisonous leaves of ignorance, the poisonous flowers of ignorance, the poisonous fruits of ignorance, delusion, greater delusion, extreme delusion, joy, greater joy, extreme joy, and the class of delusion born from delusion, are collectively called delusion.
What is anger?
There are two kinds of anger:
One is anger related to affection;
The other is anger related to non-affection.
Anger related to affection refers to the anger that arises towards parents, brothers, sisters, wives, children, and other relatives and friends.
There are those who say:
Why don't you give me this thing and give me such a thing instead?
Why don't you do this for me and do such a thing for me instead?

Because of this, all kinds of anger arise - anger, pervasive anger, extreme anger, past anger, future anger, present anger, heat, extreme heat, smoke, extreme smoke, flame, extreme flame, fierce and coarse, mind agitated and aroused, giving rise to an evil appearance, uttering evil words - this is called anger belonging to love.

Anger belonging to non-love means there is a type of person who thinks like this:ğŸ”½He now wants to do me harm, wants to do me what is not beneficial, wants to do me what is not peaceful and happy, wants to do me what is not nourishing, wants to do me what is not comfortable.

Those who wish to do harm to me, up to not wishing me to be at ease, and yet also wish to do good to them, wish to benefit them, wish them to be at ease, wish to moisten them, wish them to be at peace, and wish them to be secure.
Yet they have already done good to them, will do good to them, and are currently doing good to them.
Those who wish to do good to me, up to wishing me to be at ease, and yet also wish to do harm to them, up to not wishing them to be at ease.
Because of this, various kinds of anger arise, up to the appearance of an evil countenance and the utterance of evil words. This is called anger belonging to the unloved.
This belonging to the loved and the unloved is collectively called anger.
What is resentment?
It is when a certain type of person thinks like this:

This is able to give rise to anger, born from hatred, always harboring resentment, various kinds of resentment, pervasive resentment, extreme resentment, difficult to turn back in one's actions, bound by the fetters of one's actions, giving rise to firm actions, giving rise to enmity, giving rise to resentment, the nature of the mind being resentful, in general it is called resentment.
What is concealment?

It is a type of person who violates the precepts, violates the views, violates the pure livelihood, and violates the rules of conduct, and is unable to perfect the precepts they have received, unable to make them pure, unable to make them complete.
Having already realized their transgression for a long time, they think like this:

When they are frightened and obtain a bad reputation, bad praise, and so forth, up to being frightened of losing respect and offerings, they give rise to various concealments regarding their own transgressions, such as concealment, complete concealment, hiding, complete hiding, protection, complete protection, storage, complete storage, having concealed, will conceal, and currently conceal. What is jealousy?

There is a type of person who sees others receiving respect, offerings, reverence, and praise, as well as delightful objects of the five desires such as clothing, food and drink, bedding, medicine, and other necessities, and thinks like this:

Stinginess with possessions refers to obstructing and preventing others from obtaining the various delightful objects of the five desires such as clothing, food and drink, bedding, medicine, and other necessities.

Regarding one's own delightful possessions, one does not give, does not give everywhere, does not give according to need; one does not let go, does not let go everywhere, does not let go according to need; the nature of the mind being stingy and miserly, this is called stinginess with possessions.

What is deceit?
It refers to using false weights, measures, and scales, deceptive words, flattery, and deception to induce others to believe it is true.

What is flattery?

What is pride?

It refers to considering oneself superior to inferiors, or considering oneself equal to equals, and on this basis, the arising of pride, the state of being proud, and the mind grasping at self, in general called pride.
What is excessive pride?

That is, considering oneself equal to or superior to those who are equal or superior, and on this basis, the arising of pride and so on up to the mind grasping itself, is called excessive pride in general.
What is excessive pride?
That is, considering oneself superior to those who are superior, and on this basis, the arising of pride and so on up to the mind grasping itself, is called excessive pride in general.
What is the pride of thinking I am?

That is, observing the five appropriated aggregates as the self or what belongs to the self, and on this basis, the arising of pride and so on up to the mind grasping itself, is called the pride of thinking I am in general.
What is the pride of thinking I am superior?

That is, not having attained, thinking one has attained; not having acquired, thinking one has acquired; not having touched, thinking one has touched; not having realized, thinking one has realized, and on this basis, the arising of pride and so on up to the mind grasping itself, is called the pride of thinking I am superior in general.
What is the pride of thinking I am a little inferior?

That is, considering oneself a little inferior to those who are much superior, and on this basis, the arising of pride and so on up to the mind grasping itself, is called the pride of thinking I am a little inferior in general.
What is the pride of thinking I am?
That is, not having any virtue, one claims to have virtue, and because of this one gives rise to arrogance and even takes it upon oneself, all of which are collectively called wrong arrogance.
What is conceit?
It is a kind of thought that thinks like this:
My lineage, family, color, strength, skills, work, wealth, status, precepts, concentration, wisdom, and so forth are all superior.

Because of this, conceit arises, extreme conceit, intoxication, extreme intoxication, stupor, extreme stupor, mental arrogance, taking things upon oneself, arising, equal arising, birth, equal birth, height, extreme height, exaltation, equal exaltation, and the nature of the mind being filled, all of which are collectively called conceit.
What is negligence?

It is not cultivating, not practicing, not always doing, not constantly doing, and abandoning effort in the midst of cutting off unwholesome dharmas and accumulating wholesome dharmas, all of which are collectively called negligence.
What is arrogance?

There is a type of person who does not make offerings to those who should be offered to, does not show respect to those who should be respected, does not honor those who should be honored, does not praise those who should be praised, does not greet those who should be greeted, does not bow to those who should be bowed to, does not welcome those who should be welcomed, does not invite to sit those who should be invited to sit, and does not give way to those who should be given way to.

This gives rise to the nature of the body not being humble, not being equally humble, not being extremely humble, the body being arrogant and the mind being arrogant, and the nature of self-arrogance, which is collectively called arrogance.

It refers to the nature of the body harming, the nature of the mind harming, the nature of the body being enraged, the nature of the mind being enraged, the body being indignant, the mind being indignant, having been indignant, and being indignant in the future, which is collectively called indignation.

What is meant by delighting in evil friends?
It means there is a type of person who likes to be close to evil friends.

As for evil friends, they refer to butchers of sheep, chickens, and pigs, birdcatchers, fishermen, hunters, robbers, executioners, jailers, snake charmers, dog cookers, and those who set traps and snares. These are called evil friends.

There is also a type of person who violates the precepts, practices evil dharmas, inwardly rotten yet outwardly appearing firm, like a filthy snail with the sound of a conch and the behavior of a dog, who is not actually a Å›ramaá¹‡a yet claims to be a Å›ramaá¹‡a, and who is not actually practicing celibacy yet claims to be practicing celibacy. They are also called evil friends.
To be close to, serve, and follow such evil friends with affection is called delighting in evil friends.
What is called intolerance?
It means being unable to endure cold, heat, hunger, thirst, wind, rain, mosquitoes, gadflies, snakes, poisonous insects, and other painful things.
Again, there is a kind of person who is unable to endure the violent evil of others, the intense and rough pain that pierces the heart and takes life, the harsh and foul words that cause suffering.
This, together with the previous [kind of intolerance], is called intolerance.
What is called indulgence and excessive indulgence?
It means the lower level of the entanglements of greed, hatred, and delusion, which is called indulgence.
This middle level is called excessive indulgence.
Furthermore, the middle level of the entanglements of greed, hatred, and delusion is called indulgence.
This upper level is called excessive indulgence.
What is called defiled greed?
It means, regarding the various desires, the various kinds of greed, equal greed, up to the category of greed, the arising of greed, which is collectively called defiled greed.
What is called improper greed?
It refers to the craving and excessive craving for one's mother, daughter, sister, or any other relative, grasping and hoarding them, firmly attached and indulging in desire, called unlawful craving.
What is attachment craving?
It refers to the craving and excessive craving for one's own wealth and possessions, grasping and hoarding them, firmly attached and indulging in desire, called attachment craving.
What is evil craving?
It refers to the craving and excessive craving for others' wealth and possessions, grasping and hoarding them, firmly attached and indulging in desire, called evil craving.
Moreover, there is evil craving that schemes to take the lives of others, craving their skin, horns, and so forth, drinking their blood and eating their flesh.
These two kinds are collectively called evil craving.
What is the view of existence?
It refers to the notion of I and mine towards the five appropriated aggregates, and the acquiescence, enjoyment, wisdom, and view arising from this, called the view of existence.
What is the view of existence?
It refers to the view that the self and the world are permanent and eternal, and the acquiescence, delight, wisdom, and insight that arise from this view. This is called the view of existence.
What is the view of non-existence?

It refers to the view that the self and the world are impermanent and not eternal, and the acquiescence, delight, wisdom, and insight that arise from this view. This is called the view of non-existence.
What is craving for desire?
It refers to the desire, delight, and longing for various desirable objects, and the pursuit and aspiration for them. This is called craving for desire.
Some say that craving for desire refers to all forms of craving, such as craving for various desirable objects, and the arising of craving and the class of craving.
What is ill-will?
It refers to the wish to harm various sentient beings, harboring malice within, and even causing harm in the present. This is called ill-will.
What is torpor?
It refers to the heaviness of the body, the heaviness of the mind, and even the dullness and confusion, which are collectively called torpor.
What is sleep?
It refers to the state of sleep, which is unable to sustain the mind and has a dull and brief nature. It is generally called sleep.
What is agitation?
It refers to the mind not being tranquil, agitated and agitated, and the nature of the mind being agitated. It is generally called agitation.
What is remorse?
It refers to the mind changing, the mind being distressed, the mind regretting, my remorse, and the nature of remorse. It is generally called remorse.
What is doubt?

It refers to the arising of doubt regarding the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha, and regarding suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path, with two parts, two paths, up to not presently having a single direction. It is generally called doubt.
What is dullness?

It refers to the heaviness of the body, the heaviness of the mind, the unfitness of the body, the unfitness of the mind, the dullness of the body, the dullness of the mind, having been dull, being about to be dull, and presently being dull. It is generally called dullness.
What is displeasure?

There is a type of person who, having received the instructions and admonitions of a good teacher, a teacher's type, a preceptor, a preceptor's type, and other respected, trustworthy, and reliable friends, focuses his thoughts on dwellings and bedding, but his mind is not joyful, not loving, not delighted, but rather disappointed and sorrowful. In general, this is called lack of joy.
What is yawning and stretching?
It is the bending and raising of the body, the curling and stretching of the hands and feet, called yawning.
The opening and puckering of the nose and face, the gaping of the lips and mouth, is called stretching.
What is the nature of indigestion?
It is the arising of painful feelings due to not eating, or eating too much, or eating unwholesome food. In general, this is called the nature of indigestion.
What is the nature of mental dullness and inferiority?
It is the mental dullness, inferiority, and sluggishness in general, called the nature of mental dullness and inferiority.
What is the various thoughts?

That is, the defiled perceptions of form, sound, smell, taste, and touch possessed by one who is covered by afflictions, unwholesome perceptions, perceptions that are not conducive to reason, and perceptions that obstruct concentration, are collectively called various perceptions.
What is non-attention?

That is, with regard to the wholesome dharmas born from renunciation and seclusion, not giving rise to, not recollecting, not contemplating, not having contemplated, not intending to contemplate, and the mind being unalert, are collectively called non-attention.
What is coarseness?

That is, physical heaviness, mental heaviness, physical unserviceability, mental unserviceability, physical rigidity, mental rigidity, physical unmalleability, and mental unmalleability, are collectively called coarseness.
What is obduracy?

It means that when someone is giving food, one asks for cooked food but is given raw, asks for raw but is given cooked, asks for coarse but is given fine, asks for fine but is given coarse, is given unequally, is given unrighteously, is given without recognition or without being given, and frequently speaks contradictory words in the middle. This is called stubbornness.
Furthermore, there is a type of person who, if a preceptor, teacher, instructor, or any other respected, trustworthy, and intimate friend tells them:
Venerable!
You should do such and such tasks in order.
They think:
What many tasks are there that make me do this in order?
And frequently speaks contradictory words in the middle. This is called stubbornness.

Furthermore, there is a type of person who, whether apologizing on their own, being told to apologize by others, having their own requests, or being told to make requests by others, frequently speaks contradictory words in the middle. This is called stubbornness.
Thus, whether due to arranging clothing or engaging in work, frequently giving rise to contradictory speech, this is generally called obstinate.
What is called gluttony?
It means that when distributing wealth and benefits, one abandons one thing and takes another, with an insatiable greed, this is called gluttony.
When eating before and after, going to the place of food and drink, tasting this and sipping that, with no fixed preference for good or bad, this is called gluttony.
This, together with the previous, is generally called gluttony.
What is called unyielding nature?

It means the mind is rigid, the mind is hard and stubborn, the mind is obstinate, the mind is not clear and pure, the mind is not moist and smooth, the mind is not soft and pliable, the mind is not capable, this is generally called unyielding nature.
What is called unpliancy?

It means the body is rigid, the body is hard and stubborn, the body is obstinate, the body is not clear and pure, the body is not moist and smooth, the body is not soft and pliable, the body is not capable, this is generally called unpliancy.
How is it not in accord with one's kind?

It means that there is a type of person who does not properly follow their own teachers, preceptors, and other respected, trustworthy, and intimate friends. This is called not being in accord with one's kind.
What is desire-based discursive thought?

It means the discursive thought, thorough search, close search, manifestation of mind, extreme manifestation, manifestation in the present, speculation, imagination, and deliberation associated with desire and greed. In general, it is called desire-based discursive thought.
What is anger-based discursive thought?
It means the discursive thought, thorough search, up to deliberation and discrimination associated with hatred. In general, it is called anger-based discursive thought.
What is harm-based discursive thought?
It means the discursive thought, thorough search, up to deliberation and discrimination associated with harm. In general, it is called harm-based discursive thought.
What is family-based discursive thought?

That is to say, one wishes to bring peace and happiness to one's relatives, to obtain excellent companions, to be free from harm, to accomplish all the dharmas free from harm, to be loved by kings and ministers, to be admired by the people of the country, for the five grains to ripen well, and for the rain to fall in a timely manner.
On the basis of these, one gives rise to mental seeking, thorough seeking, and so forth, up to conceptualization and discrimination, which are collectively called seeking relatives.
What is seeking one's country?
That is to say, one wishes to bring peace and happiness to the people of the country one loves, and so forth, up to the rain falling in a timely manner.
On the basis of these, one gives rise to mental seeking, thorough seeking, and so forth, up to conceptualization and discrimination, which are collectively called seeking one's country.

Thinking like this, they do not understand the fragility of their own life, and give rise to thoughts seeking, seeking everywhere, up to contemplating and discriminating, which is collectively called immortality seeking.
What is the seeking of contempt?
It means a certain type of thought:
My lineage, family, color, strength, skills, work, wealth, status, precepts, concentration, wisdom, and so forth are all superior.
Relying on this, they look down on others.
Because of this and so forth, they give rise to thoughts seeking, seeking everywhere, up to contemplating and discriminating, which is collectively called the seeking of contempt.
What is the seeking of false lineage?

There is a type of person who, regarding those who are not relatives as relatives, wishes to bring them peace and happiness, to obtain excellent companions, to be free from harm, to accomplish all dharmas free from harm, to be loved by kings and ministers, to be respected by the people of the country, to have abundant harvests of the five grains, and to have timely rainfall.
Because of these, one gives rise to a mind that seeks and thoroughly seeks, up to contemplating and discriminating, which is collectively called seeking relatives through pretense.
What is sorrow?

There is a type of person who, because of the death of parents, siblings, friends, or teachers, or because of the complete destruction of relatives, or because of the loss of wealth and status, gives rise to a fierce, rough, and cruel mind that cuts off life and experiences painful and bitter suffering.

At that time, the mind is hot, equally hot, internally hot, and pervasively hot, and one gives rise to sorrow, has sorrowed, will sorrow, and has the arrow of sorrow in the mind, which is collectively called sorrow.
What is lamentation?
There is a type of person who, due to the death of parents, siblings, friends, or teachers, etc., gives rise to suffering up to painful feelings in their own body.
At that time, their mind is agitated up to a sorrowful arrow in the mind.
Because of this condition, they lament and say:
Alas, alas!
How is it that my father, my mother, and so on up to my wealth and position, have suddenly come to this?
The words of lamentation and various verbal actions contained therein are collectively called lamentation.
What is suffering?
The unequal feelings associated with the five consciousnesses are collectively called suffering.
What is sorrow?
The unequal feelings associated with the mental consciousness are collectively called sorrow.
What is agitation?
It refers to the agitation of the mind, the already agitated, the to-be agitated, the nature of agitation, and the type of agitation, which are collectively called agitation.
From greed, anger, and delusion up to agitation, all are called miscellaneous matters.
